Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is not backed up by any evidence or data.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that a "regulatory thing" is the reason why someone can't be shown drinking beer on camera in commercials, without providing any evidence or explanation for this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The expert provides an alternative explanation by stating that it is not the government or regulatory bodies that prohibit drinking on camera in beer commercials, but rather the TV networks and broadcasters who have their own rules and standards.
Understate: The claim understates the complexity of the issue by simplifying it to a single "regulatory thing" without acknowledging the various factors and stakeholders involved in setting the rules for beer commercials.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there are no specific laws or regulations prohibiting drinking on camera in beer commercials, as stated by the Federal Communications Commission.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear and well-supported argument or explanation for the "regulatory thing" mentioned.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the impact of the "regulatory thing" by presenting it as a major obstacle to showing someone drinking beer on camera, without providing sufficient evidence or context.
